comments.text: Printing with the face pointing straight up I had one side of the print come off the print bed at about half way. I've increased the brim from 10mm to 20mm for better print adhesion. Replacement for the original extruder mount of the bcn3d sigma. This mount fits a 5.5W laser such as this: https://es.aliexpress.com/item/5-5w-high-power-450NM-focusing-blue-laser-module-laser-engraving-and-cutting-TTL-module-5500mw/32559183201.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.MlrGmy

I mounted the laser as second extruder, so i can print and engrave/cut without having to do any modifications except covering the Printbed during laser usage.

Using the TTL input of the laser the power can also be adjusted to support engraving and cutting in one pass.

Additionally needed:

  • Laser module (see above)
  • Four M2.5 screws to fit the aluminum block of the laser.
  • Two M3 screws to fit the electronics of the laser
    For the Fan connection:
  • an N-Fet (i.e. 2N7002)
  • a view resistors (see schematic)
  • the molex type of fan connector (I cut it off an extruder fan I had as spare part but a pin header connector will do as well)
  • the molex type of extruder connector (I cut it off an extruder I had as spare part but a pin header connector will do as well i guess)
  • a 12kOhms resistor to simulate the now missing extruder temperature sensor.
  • wires and a power supply

ATTENTION: Make sure to always have the printer powered as long as the laser power supply is powered, else the laser will burn at full power until the printer is switched on.

AND: If you cancel a print during laser operation be aware the the current firmware will not turn off the laser during homing, so first cut the laser supply and then cancel the print.

Happy hacking :)

title: Makeadrone motor mounts for 720 motor and ice sticks

description.text:
Speed up your print with these motor mounts to be used together with ice cream sticks (9.5mm wide, 2mm thick). Printing takes approximately one hour for 4 mounts.

One version is adjustable and slides over the stick, so you can decide the motor to motor distance, in case you want to fit propeller protection etc. The other snaps in at the end of the sticks.

Glue the sticks like a cross before adding the motor mounts. Apply some eva foam or foam tape underneath the sticks as landing gear. Use rubber bands to hold the electronics board and the battery.

You can buy a kit with all the electronics here: https://makeadrone.net/collections/komplette-byggesett/products/makeadrone-mikro-klassesett-5-forsterkede-kameradroner-for-gjenbruk

description.text:
Simplistic open-faced box to hold CNC bits that ship in their own individual plastic containers.

Could probably be a little deeper. We fit them with the bits inverted, but the bit holders are flexible and you can flip them and press-fit the base into the insets. The insets are a bit too close together to grab bits this way, but it's workable. We like the loose fit--makes it trivial to grab what you want.

The picture has two sizes of bit containers, short and tall--there is no step built in to the design. The file(s) with the word "Tiered" in it have ~0.25" tiers for each row.

After coming into a plethora of bits, which Inventables ships in convenient plastic holders, I needed an easy way to keep them upright and visible, and for now I wanted to keep them in their containers instead of having an open-style bit holder. They're sharp, and we're clumsy--too easy to open yourself up reaching for a bit in the back, don'tcha know.

I use the same base with the post glued to it. This post is sized for 9 beads, 10 if you want push it. Stretch along the Z axis to make longer if needed. Each bead is set to be 5mm high and post is 50mm.

I use the same base so you are able to have written messages about the condition, you can print in different colors to mark different conditions or even paint. Make marks on it to represent counts of 5, 10, 50 or what ever you need, if you need conditions that last longer than 10 counts.

My oldest daughter (9 Years old) and I designed and assembled these braille tiles that can be glued to a Rubik's Cube. Following the idea of Universal Design (Example - Curb cuts help people using a wheelchair, but also parents pushing a stroller) I try to create things that a sighted person and a person who is blind can work together on. If someone is color blind they can also use different color plastic to accommodate for the colors they can't differentiate.
The braille is follows Grade 1 and is just the first letter of the Color:
G = Green
Y=Yellow
O=Orange
W=White (W and red are can be confused so a T could be substituted)
R=Red
B=Blue
The next feature is that we added an orientation line at the bottom of each tile. This allows as the cube is turned that the braille user know where the bottom of each tile is. If you notice in my picture I already mixed it up so the orientation are not lined up perfectly (bonus points if you could get it back to all orientation lines are on the bottom)
I used an Ultimaker 3 extended, I extended the brim to 14mm to make 10 tiles (1 extra just in case), moved them close to each other 5x5 and increased the bed temp to 100c at layer height of .06mm. 20% infill (but none was needed). When separating the tiles they can be snapped off then trimmed. I used a CHP-170 snipper to get a clean cut around each tile. Then used Krazy Clue with a brush to apply adhesive. All filament was Matterhacker ABS PRO which printed great and should hold up to the high temperatures of where I live.

This was the Envision the Future challenge winner. A challenge that was put on by enable the future, the 3D printing hands non-profit.

It's a fun project and can be educational.
This can be a project for students to learn how to use 3D printing to make things accessible. You can also use it as a way to introduce braille to students.

Materials

3D printer, filament, krazy glue, clippers, and a rubriks cube

author: TeamStandoff

description.text:
Man's first invention was the stick, used to keep bad things away.
Man's second invention was the rope, used to keep good things close.

Here's a thing used in the making of something that holds things together.

No more picking sticks up off the ground or using the one that came with your paint or epoxy or contact cement, that bullpucky's for chumps. You're not a chump, are you? Of course not, else a handsome chap like you wouldn't be here learning the best and most efficient way to create your very own stick through the wondrous process of 3D printing.

It's like ordinary printing, but with DEPTH, the kind of depth that a fine, enterprising captain of industry like yourself possesses in spades and uses to ponder those great mysteries of life like, "How can I stir this 2-part epoxy without getting my hands all sticky or making my as-of-yet-uneaten popsicle inedible?" Wonder no more,

All this can be your's for the low, low, nonexistent price of not a damn thing because IT'S A STICK. See, stick! Stick, stupid!
Psh!
No wonder you're extinct.

Kidding and extinction events aside, this is legitimately useful if you don't mind the wait time of about 30 minutes, and there's something to be said about a, um, stick you can set exacting specifications for, like thickness and overall shape. Maybe you need one end flat and wide to spread the glue around once you're done using the other, thinner and narrower end to stir the stuff that needs spreading. Maybe the stirring part can have holes or grooves in it to better move the mixture around more thoroughly and evenly. Maybe you need a logo on it so the welt you leave on someone's skin reminds them who they dared to mess wi--er, anyway, if you're going to make your own tools, do it with a sense of purpose and style.

Maybe I'll try my hand at making a customizer. I need an excuse to spend more quality time with OpenSCAD.

I highly recommend to print it like seen on the picture. There is a lot of force on it!
If your wires are 2 Meters long and you make one rotation per second you get about 7kg on it and easily 20kg wenn you make two rotations per second. So please first hang 20 kg at the handle to see whether it is stable enough! Use wires which can at least holt 7kg each (3*7kg=21kg). You will probably never make 2 rotations per second, but safty first!

The tablet holder is not standing itself, therefore the extra stand for behind. But with the tablet included it will also stand alone without the back holder.

I hope you will also have fun with my solution and if you have something in mind for making it better or adding more just please tell me.
I also thinking of an additional dust cover.

So have fun guys and Happy Printing,

Patrick

title: Tool to level X-axis of Prusa i3

description.text:
Customizable X-axis leveling tool designed for Prusa i3 Berlin. Used to make sure that each side of the X-axis is at the same height. Necessary since there's a stepper motor on each side and they can get out of step.
To use:
Place "forked" end of tool on Y smooth rod and use Z control to bring the X axis just above the flat part of the top of the tool. Manually rotate the Z rod for that side so the X carriage rod just touches the bottom of the "L" at the top of the tool. Adjust the other side the same way. Go back and forth to each side a few times to get the X-axis rod level.
IMPORTANT: Don't squish the tool between the rods by using the Z motor control - this could put pressure on the smooth rods and possibly bend them. Doing the final adjustment by hand works best.
I've been using this tool for awhile now and it works pretty well. One improvement would be if it had a hook to hang down from the X-axis rod instead of being squished between X-axis rod and Y-axis rod. Then you could hang one of the tools on each side of the X-axis rod and adjust them at the same time.

Successfully printed using 0.2mm layer height, 1.0mm shell width and 30% infill density.  Square or triangular shapes might be more accurate than the curves that touch the smooth rods.  Happy to see a remix!

description.text:
Hi!

This is the first of some collections to come. It's about Conway's Game of Life.

The main goal in my mind was to obtain a 3D printable representation of the Conway´s automatons to show how ordered structures could emerge from a chaotic state just following simple rules. The result was some sort of weird architectural stuff.

Once developped a crappy software to run the concept i just can't stop generating and saving models. So i've upload 60 files ready to print!!!

60 STL's and their thumbnails included in ZIP files (see thumbnails below)

Nice for decoration or as scenery for tabletop games.

Generated procedurally using [Processing] (www.processing.org)

Easy to print, no supports required. See below for some printing tips.

Hope you like it.

Have fun!!

title: Reinforced 3 bolt Y axis motor mount for Prusa i3 mk3

description.text:
Update 3/10/18 - I checked the motor mount in a 3D model of the prusa i3 mk3 with r2 components by jzkmath. The motor mount still works beautifully and still corrects any misalignment that is inherent in the stock mount.

I read a lot of comments from people asking if a third screw was able to be added to the motor mount so I decided to go back to the model and investigate this. I fount that I was able to do so easily by adjusting some bolt lengths and tweaking some features on the original motor mount.

I originally didn't want to reprint the motor mount due to the .5mm offset that is standard on the printer since this is a minimal error and is probably negligible. However since I had to make the mount more rigid as well as add the third bolt, I figured I would correct this misalignment in the process.

This mount is intended to be used with the stock belt holder only. With this mount there is no longer any misalignment of any type. I also added 1.5mm to the face of the mount so that the motor was moved to the side. This places the motor shaft in the proper location so that the pulley is centered on the shaft. This gives an even amount of side to side adjustment of the pulley location. so there no more issues with belt rubbing due to a lack of pulley adjustment. This also pairs nicely to the adjustable belt tensioner that I designed (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2786671) and with this combination along with the stock belt holder, there is perfect belt parallelism as well as no belt misalignment.

Unfortunately in adding the third screw, some hardware must be replaced from the stock setup. You will need two m3 x 30mm socket head cap screws and one m3 x 16mm (longer wont hurt) socket head cap screw. All the other hardware remains the same. See the assembly drawing for screw locations.

Thank you again to jweaver for testing as well as the pictures!!!

This is my first attempt at designing something for this community that I would like to share. It's for all of us kids at heart that would like to nostalgic with vintage toys again as well as letting our children know how old toys are made and supposed to play about.

This is my attempt at making a simple vintage pecking chicken toy.
There are strings attached to the heads of the chickens and are weighed in at the other end by a weight (egg)

The basic concept is to let the weight (egg) weigh below the toy and spin the weight round and let the heads of the chickens hit the center of the paddle exactly like pecking food from the ground.

It's a simple design that can easily be printed, can easily be assembled, with no need for any adhesives, and very fun to make.

title: Orville Data Pad
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: This a working version of the glowing data pad used on the Orville. It uses 3D printed parts and 1/4 inch thick plexyglas

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 or finer

Infill:

60%

Notes:

This was designed with individual cosplayers and hobbyists in mind, so the bad news is, the files are set up non-commercial, no derivatives. If you want to make one for yourself or make one and give it away, good on you, mate.

After printing, cut away the triangle supports on the side to give better access to the inside for wiring. Do any painting you may need. Assemble the electronics. I used a rechargeable 3.6 volt battery pack from a cordless phone ($6 for a pair online). I made my two prong plug from LED leads soldered to nine inches of thin wire, then covered it with a glob of marine epoxy. Stripping the insulation away at various points made the wire up easy. The middle LED is ground down and polished to make it a floodlight, with the outside LEDs working as spotlights all the way up the screen.
For the screen material, I used a plexyglas sheet I got on amazon, cut to 140mm x 95mm with a rounded corner.
Clear Acrylic Plexiglas Sheet 8" X 12", 1/4" (pack of 2) enough for six datapads
https://www.amazon.com/Clear-Acrylic-Plexiglas-Sheet-pack/dp/B00YV5M7EM/ref=sr_1_8?ie=UTF8&qid=1519692674&sr=8-8&keywords=1%2F4+acrylic
After cutting out and doing any filing, use a palm sander and sand all surfaces with 300 then 500 grit sandpaper. Then wet sand the bottom edge and buff with a felt wheel (dremel) back to clear. This is the surface the LEDs will shine through. Make some thin shims by cutting thick plastic sheet scraps into toothpick like wedges and sand the tips to a flat knife point. These will give you the space you need to fit the display onto the screen. Epoxy the screen in the frame by putting small amounts of epoxy ONLY on the inside back and side edge. Nothing on the front edge. Slide the screen in and wedge the shims in the front, forcing the screen back against the epoxy and keeping a gap of several hundreths of an inch in the front. After the epoxy has hardened, repeat the process with the corner tip, shimming it for a front gap. You will be able to slide the display in the gap and the frame and tip will hold it in place flat against the screen.
The screen displays are made by printing the images on transparency sheets at photo quality. I used a hair dryer to preheat the sheet and fanned it across the printer output opening to dry the ink as soon as possible and mitigate any spalling or droplets forming on the plastic. After drying for an hour, cut out the image just inside the outline and coat the surface with two light coats of artist matte fixative spray. This prevents handling from smearing the display. Test fit and trim if needed.
Install the electronics with small beads of marine epoxy. Dont get any on the moving part of the micro slide switch. Test the circuit. If everything works, you can attach the battery cap using the molded ribbed side panel as an index. With the cap in place, epoxy the remaining ribbed side, using the cap as your reference. Do not get any epoxy on the cap! A fully charged battery will give you many hours of use.
Screen caps and TinkerCad to design.

A short video of 2nd process being printed: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lwOmZVP7mz4

Printer Brand:

Creality

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15%

Notes:

This can be printed with a single color/process (and then later painted, if desired), but I sliced it as a multi-process job (as I never tried it before), so will offer here my (S3D) settings if you wanted to go down that road.

Position:
X Offset: 37.21 mm
Y Offset: 71.00 mm
Z Offset: 8.00 mm

Scaling:
Scale: 100%

Rotation: 0 deg (all axes)

Processes:
Process1: hex nut cap (and a small part of "mane" from the head)

  • Advanced tab / Layer Modifications / Stop printing at height: 8.80

Process2: dragon head

  • Advanced tab / Layer Modifications / Start printing at height: 8.80

Supports are needed (sparsely) under the cap, but not from the outside.

Orientational time and costs:
Build time: 0 hours 23 minutes
Filament length: 1531.4 mm
Plastic weight: 4.60 g (0.01 lb)
Material cost: 0.14

• measured and drew the hex nut cap in F360
  • added a circular background (as a head motif would look better on it than on hex)
  • extruded the head from a simplified logo version I captured from the device boot screen (see original Thing / Remixed From for details)

print_settings.Notes:: All parts in 0.2mm, except the cutting blade in 0.1mm to ensure have sharp dents

description.text:
I made this dispenser to avoid me to use 2 hands to pull the tapes and cut it properly.

At the beginning, it was for one sort of tape, finaly, i added more sorts.

As is, this dispenser can hold 4 dimensions, but you can adapt it easily:

1 x 19 mm
1 x 25 mm
1 x 35 mm
1 x 50 mm

All with standard 76mm support (mandrel), and with 130mm max diameter for the tape roll.

To be usefull, you'll need to add lead or another heavy metal in the bottom part (called "bac à plomb"). You can put approx 1.5 kg !!!

To build your own dispenser you'll have to print:
1 Left Holder (Flanc gauche.stl)
1 Right Holder (Flanc droit.stl)
1 Bottom part (Bac à plomb.stl)
5 Separators (Séparateur.stl), to avoid contact between 2 rolls)
8 Half supports (demi mandrin.stl)
1 Blade holder (Barre avant.stl)
1 Blade (Lame.stl)

Edit 2018/03/01: Some mandrels of lowcost tape rolls are not exactly 76mm diameter. So i add today 3 spacers than can be positionned on the M6 rod, between half supports. That insure the half support to not move.

Edit 2018/03/02: Photo of finished thing added

1 5 mm spacer (entretoise 5mm.stl)
1 15 mm spacer (entretoise 15mm.stl)
1 30 mm spacer (entretoise 30mm.stl)

Make it fun !!!

EDIT 2018/03/03:

The screws on the blade are a problem, as the tape does'nt touch the blade correctly. So i changed the design of the blade (4mm thickness instead of 2 mm, and had hole to insure the head of the screew to be under the surface of the blade).

You can find the new stl file : (Lame V2.stl) in the thing files.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

All parts in 0.2mm, except the cutting blade in 0.1mm to ensure have sharp dents

A few actions

Make the thread of the holes of the sides of the blade holder (M3), and the same on the upper side, with M2. There are only marks to be adaptable with the screw or bolts you have.

To assemble, you just need:

1 x M6 rod, lenght = 148.50 mm (for rolls axis),
6 x M3 x 10 Hexa bolts,
6 x M3 nuts for the left and right side,
4 x M3 x 10 Hexa bolts for blade holder assembly with left and right side
4 x M2x5 for the cutting blade on the blade holder.

Blade can also be glued, if you prefere, but with time, i think that it must be changed. For the moment i don't know.

1.5 Kg of lead or other heavy thing

More "Why" i designed than "How"

I use frequently adhesive tape of differents sizes.

Each time i had to use my both hands to pull tape and cut it.

With this dispenser of 2Kg, just one hand needed.

Dog poop bag holder / dispenser and leash holder attachment.

I only uploaded the most basic version. I've made a few custom ones for a local pet store and a few friends.

I know it seems weird but the body can be printed upright without supports if your printer is good with bridging. obviously use your best judgment, you know your printer better than I do.
